facts.text: Appellant is the present holder of Taluk Kakwara which appertains to Mahalat Kharakpur.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents represent the Banaili Raj which has also acquired the Mahalat of Kharakpur.

facts.text: On August 29, 1939, the appellant judgment-debtor filed an objection under section 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure alleging that Taluk Kakwara was held on Ghatwali tenure and could not be sold in execution of a money decree.

facts.text: Principal question in execution proceedings was whether Taluk Kakwara was a Government Ghatwali as alleged by appellant or Zamindari Ghatwali as claimed by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The principal question for determination in those execution proceedings was whether Taluk Kakwara was a Government Ghatwali, as alleged by the appellant judgment-debtor, or was a Zamindari

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Bhagalpur held that Taluk Kakwara was a Zamindari Ghatwali under the Raja of Kharakpur and overruled the objection.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge held that Taluk Kakwara was a Zamindari Ghatwali under the Raja of Kharakpur and overruled the objection of the judgment-debtor.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor appealed to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor appealed to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court Bench: Manohar Lal J held Taluk Kakwara was Government Ghatwali, inclined to allow appeal; Shearer J held it ceased to be Government and became Zamindari Ghatwali, inclined to dismiss.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal came up for hearing in the first instance before a Bench consisting of Manohar Lal and Shearer JJ. Manohar Lal J. came to the conclusion that Taluk Kakwara was a Government Ghatwali

facts.text: Appeal referred to Chatterjee J as third Judge who held Taluk Kakwara was Zamindari Ghatwali and dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this difference of opinion the appeal was referred to Chatterjee J, as the third Judge Chatterjee J. held that Taluk Kakwara was a Zamindari Ghatwali land

facts.text: Judgment-debtor obtained leave to appeal to the Privy Council.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Taluk Kakwara was Zamindari Ghatwali tenure, alienable with assent of Zamindar.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the facts and the circumstances mentioned above, we are of opinion that Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure

facts.text: In 1765 East India Company secured Dewani of Bengal, Bihar and Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: In 1765 the East India Company secured the Dewani of Bengal, Bihar and Orissa from the Moghul Emperor.

facts.text: Captain Browne granted Sanad (Exhibit 1) in 1776/1777 to Rankoo Singh and Bhairo Singh for 22 villages of Taluk Kakwara at fixed jama Rs. 245-12-15.

anchor.surface_text: In 1776 Captain Browne, who was then in charge of the Mahalat, granted an Amalnama or Sanad (Exhibit 1) in respect of 22 villages to two persons Rankoo Singh and Bhairo Singh

facts.text: On January 17, 1780, Raja Kadir Ali granted Sanad (Exhibit 1a) to Rankoo Singh and Bhairo Singh for Taluk Kakwara.

anchor.surface_text: On January 17, 1780, a fresh Sanad (Exhibit 1 a) was granted in the name and under the Seal of Raja Kadir All to the same two persons

facts.text: Taluk Kakwara included in Permanent Settlement of Mahalat Kharakpur in 1793/1796.

anchor.surface_text: In 1789 or 1790 there was a decennial settlement of Mahalat Kharakpur with Raja Kadir Ali which in 1796 was made permanent under the permanent Settlement Regulation I of 1793.

issues.text: to which class the Ghatwali tenure of Taluk Kakwara, with which we are concerned in this case, belongs--whether it was a Government Ghatwali or was one of the many Ghatwali tenures created by the Zamindars of Kharakpur

anchor.surface_text: The question, then, is--to which class the Ghatwali tenure of Taluk Kakwara, with which we are concerned in this case, belongs--whether it was a Government Ghatwali or was one of the many Ghatwali tenures created by the Zamindars of Kharakpur. Happily, we do not have to speculate.

issues.answer: one of the many Ghatwali tenures created by the Zamindars of Kharakpur

arguments.claim: Commencement from 1184 Fasli and payment to Government treasury indicate new Government grant

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the grant was to commence from the beginning of 1184 Fasli also militates against its being only a confirmation of a pre-existing Ghatwali tenure. The direction to pay according to the Kabuliat, year after year, crop after crop, into the Government treasury clearly suggests that the Sanad created a Government Ghatwali tenure.

arguments.claim: Fixed jama not confirmation as Moghul grants varied annually

anchor.surface_text: In the Moghul period there was no fixity of the jama and the grants were made annually and the jamas were liable to be varied. The provision of a fixed annual jama in this Sanad cannot, therefore, it is argued, be regarded as a confirmation of an existing grant on a fixed jama.

arguments.claim: Kharakpur Ghatwali tenures alienable with assent of Zamindar per custom in Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, in Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy which related to the Ghatwali Mahal of Kharna within the Mahalat of Kharakpur the evidence clearly established a number of instances

arguments.claim: Custom of alienability in Kharakpur does not apply to independent Government Ghatwalis like Handwa per Narayan Singh

anchor.surface_text: In the later case of Narayan Singh v. Niranjan Chakravarti which related to the Ghatwali Mahal of Handwa, Lord Sumner recognised that the decision of the Privy Council in the Kharna Ghatwali Mahal case was fully supported by the evidence adduced in that case and that that authority had been repeatedly followed and applied in India, and, so far as the reports showed, without proof of the custom being required over again.

arguments.claim: Ghatwali tenures in Kharakpur are Zamindari, alienable with assent; Government ones inalienable

anchor.surface_text: In short, it may be said to be well established--and the contrary has not been urged before us --that Ghatwali tenures held under the Zamindar of Kharakpur were, by custom judicially recognised, alienable with the assent of the Zamindar while Ghatwali tenures like Handwa held under the Government direct were inalienable.

arguments.claim: Captain Browne's Sanad confirms existing Zamindari tenure; duties like ordinary Zamindar duties; no stipulation for fixed armed force

arguments.claim: Taluk Kakwara included in Permanent Settlement as part of Zamindari; not resumable

anchor.surface_text: In 1789 or 1790 there was a decennial settlement of Mahalat Kharakpur with Raja Kadir Ali which in 1796 was made permanent under the permanent Settlement Regulation I of 1793.

arguments.claim: Lists of 1860 and 1863 show Kakwara as Zamindari Ghatwali under Kharakpur

anchor.surface_text: On February 24, 1860, a list (Exhibit D) of Ghatwali Mahals appertaining to Kharakpur was prepared by the Government showing 98 Ghatwali tenures appertaining to Mahal Kharakpur.

arguments.claim: Taluk Kakwara is Zamindari Ghatwali tenure, alienable with Zamindar assent per Kharakpur custom

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the facts and the circumstances mentioned above, we are of opinion that Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure

arguments.claim: Handwa distinct from Kakwara: no rasoom, direct payment to treasury, not in lists, sanad from Collector, appointment disputed

holdings.text: Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time and further that even if by virtue of Captain Brownes Sanad it became a Government Ghatwali tenure, then under the Sanad of Raja Kadir Ali, or, at any rate, after the Permanent Settlement, Taluk Kakwara became a Zamindari Ghatwali and as such alienable with the consent of the Zamindar according to the custom of Kharakpur judicially recognised.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the facts and the circumstances mentioned above, we are of opinion that Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of sanads (Browne and Kadir Ali), inclusion in Permanent Settlement jama, government lists of 1860/1863, historical treatment, distinction from Handwa, consistency with precedents like Raja Lelanund Singh.

holdings.text: Ghatwali tenures held under the Zamindar of Kharakpur were, by custom judicially recognised, alienable with the assent of the Zamindar while Ghatwali tenures like Handwa held under the Government direct were inalienable.

anchor.surface_text: In short, it may be said to be well established--and the contrary has not been urged before us --that Ghatwali tenures held under the Zamindar of Kharakpur were, by custom judicially recognised, alienable with the assent of the Zamindar while Ghatwali tenures like Handwa held under the Government direct were inalienable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council precedents in Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy (Kharna) and Narayan Singh v. Niranjan Chakravarti (Handwa distinction); custom requires no fresh proof.

holdings.text: A sale at the instance of the Zamindar in execution of a decree for arrears of rent necessarily implies the existence of such assent.

anchor.surface_text: A sale at the instance of the Zamindar in execution of a decree for arrears of rent necessarily implies the existence of such assent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical implication from custom requiring Zamindar assent for alienation; respondents as Zamindar seeking execution provide assent.

holdings.text: The Ghatwali tenure of Taluk Kakwara belongs to the class of many Ghatwali tenures created by the Zamindars of Kharakpur.

anchor.surface_text: The question, then, is--to which class the Ghatwali tenure of Taluk Kakwara, with which we are concerned in this case, belongs--whether it was a Government Ghatwali or was one of the many Ghatwali tenures created by the Zamindars of Kharakpur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly answered by evidence of sanads, Permanent Settlement treatment, and lists confirming Zamindari origin over Government claim.

holdings.text: The conclusions arrived at are in no way inconsistent with the judicial decisions which have been cited before us.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear to us that the conclusions arrived at by us are in no way inconsistent with the judicial decisions which have been cited before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reconciles with Raja Lelanund Singh, Munrunjan Singh, Leelanund Singh v. Thakoor Munrunjun Singh, Narayan Singh; distinguishes Handwa facts.

precedents.cited_proposition: Ghatwali tenures in Kharakpur Mahals are alienable with assent of the Zamindar
precedents.cited_holding: the true view to take was that such a tenure in Kharakpur was number inalienable, and might be transferred by the Ghatwal or sold in execution of a decree against him, if such transfer or sale was assented to by the Zamindar

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between Kharakpur Zamindari Ghatwalis (alienable with assent) and independent Government Ghatwalis like Handwa (inalienable)
precedents.cited_holding: the custom of Kharakpur had any application to Ghatwali tenures, which, like Handwa, were independent of the Kharakpur Zamindari

precedents.case_name: Raja Lelanund Singh v Government of Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Description of Zamindars' position and origin of Ghatwali tenures under Mahomedan rulers
precedents.cited_holding: To prevent these incursions it was necessary to guard and watch the Ghats... established a tenure called Ghatwali ten- ure, by which lands were granted to individuals... on companydition of their performing these duties

anchor.surface_text: In short, it may be said to be well established--and the contrary has not been urged before us --that Ghatwali tenures held under the Zamindar of Kharakpur were, by custom judicially recognised, alienable with the assent of the Zamindar while Ghatwali tenures like Handwa held under the Government direct were inalienable.

On a consideration of the facts and the circumstances mentioned above, we are of opinion that Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time and further that even if by virtue of Captai
nst him, if such transfer or sale was assented to by the Zamindar. A sale at the

edges.explanation: Holding explains that a sale by the Zamindar in execution of a rent decree implies assent, relevant to the alienability of Taluk Kakwara in a money decree execution.

anchor.surface_text: A sale at the instance of the Zamindar in execution of a decree for arrears of rent necessarily implies the existence of such assent.

anchor.surface_text: The question, then, is--to which class the Ghatwali tenure of Taluk Kakwara, with which we are concerned in this case, belongs--whether it was a Government Ghatwali or was one of the many Ghatwali tenures created by the Zamindars of Kharakpur.

On a consideration of the facts and the circumstances mentioned above, we are of opinion that Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time and further that even if by virtue of Captai
